{{Infobox Union |name= ''EUROCADRES'' |country= Europe |associated= [[ETUC]] |members= 6 million from national trade union organisations in Europe and European Trade Union Federations |full_name= Council of European Professional and Managerial Staff |native_name= |founded= 1993 |image= |current= |head= |dissolved_date= |dissolved_state= |merged_into= |office= Brussels, Belgium |people= Martin Jefflén, President 2013-; Carlo Parietti, President 2006-2012; - Michel Rousselot, President 1993-2005 |website= [http://www.eurocadres.eu/ www.eurocadres.eu] |footnotes= }}
The '''Council of European Professional and Managerial Staff (''EUROCADRES'')''' is an recognised<ref>http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/industrial-relations-dictionary/eurocadres</ref> cross-industry [[social partner]] in the European [[Social dialogue|Social Dialogue]]<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/social/main.jsp?catId=329&langId=en</ref> and in collective bargaining, representing Professional and Managerial Staff (P&MS) in Europe.<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/social/BlobServlet?docId=2154&langId=en</ref> ''EUROCADRES'' is associated to the [[European Trade Union Confederation]] (ETUC), but is fully independent and addresses only Professional and Managerial Staff issues. At European level ''EUROCADRES'' participates, in association with [[CEC European Managers|CEC - European Managers]], in the cross-industry social dialogue with [[Trade union|workers' representatives]] - [[European Trade Union Confederation|European Trade Union Confederation - ETUC]], and [[Employers' organization|employers' representatives]] -[[BUSINESSEUROPE]], [[CEEP|CEEP - European Centre of Enterprises with Public Participation and of Enterprises of General Economic Interest]], [[UEAPME|UEAPME - European Association of Craft and Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises]].<ref>List of consulted cross-industry social partners http://ec.europa.eu/social/BlobServlet?docId=2154&langId=en</ref> With more than 15% of employees holding professional or managerial positions, ''EUROCADRES'' represents<ref>http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/areas/industrialrelations/dictionary/definitions/REPRESENTATIVENESS.htm</ref> almost 6 million employees in all sectors of business, in industry as well as in the civil and public services.<ref>http://www.eurocadres.org/</ref>
''EUROCADRES'' convenes its Congress, which is the policy-making body, every four years. In the intervening years, affiliates are summoned to a General Assembly. All ''EUROCADRES'' activities and policies between Congresses are controlled by the Executive Committee with national representatives and industry federation delegates including the President and Vice-Presidents elected by a secret ballot of the Congress. The President (Martin Jefflén, Swedish) represents ''EUROCADRES'' in cooperation with the Vice-Presidents.
The Secretariat is located in Brussels.
== History == In 1992, the [[European Union]] entered into a new phase, after the signature of the [[Maastricht treaty]] that opened the way to the [[Euro]] and [[Social partners|recognised the role of social partners]], with the setting up of a framework for [[social dialogue]]. In parallel, the [[trade union movement]] had just marked a new milestone: the seventh ETUC (European trade union confederation) congress in 1991 modernised the structures and opened the door to the [[Trade union federation|European sectoral entities]] as member [[organisations]].
From then on, the European dimension was to play a crucial role.<ref>The legal basis for the consultation of social partners is today embedded in Art 154-155 of the [http://Treaty%20on%20the%20Functioning%20of%20the%20European%20Union TFUE]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} - http://eur-lex.europa.eu/LexUriServ/LexUriServ.do?uri=OJ:C:2008:115:0047:0199:EN:PDF</ref>
[[Professional]] and [[Managerial|managerial staff]], whose numbers were growing, were actively involved in the economic and social life of all [[European countries]]. They were members of many different types of organisation. In the various countries, the professionals' and managers' national organisations, with their work experience within the FIET ([[International Federation of Commercial, Clerical, Professional and Technical Employees]]) Committee for professional and managerial staff, or within NAR (Nordic Professional Council), wanted to be provided with an organisation able to represent them and to act at European level. Thus ''EUROCADRES'' was born, on 24 February 1993 in Luxembourg.
Delegates represented 40 organisations and came from 15 countries. They decided to establish the Council of European Professional and Managerial Staff under the name ''EUROCADRES''. Bertil Blomqvist (Sweden) and Peter Lamb (United Kingdom) were elected Vice Presidents whilst Michel Rousselot (France) was elected President. The action programme adopted by the Assembly covered employment, [[Mobility rights|mobility]], [[training]], the roles of professional and managerial staff, management methods, [[working conditions]] and [[equal opportunities]] and served as the basis for action taken by ''EUROCADRES''. Soon after, ''EUROCADRES'' took the European stage by joining the Europe-wide demonstration organised by the ETUC on 2 April 1993 calling for a coordinated employment policy. In 1999 a joint agreement<ref>[http://www.eurofound.europa.eu/observatories/eurwork/articles/managerial-and-professional-unions-agree-to-cooperate-in-european-social-dialogue] EurWORK European Observatory of Working Life, Article 27 August 1999: Managerial and professional unions agree to cooperate in European social dialogue</ref> with [https://www.cec-managers.org/ CEC European Managers] was signed. In 2013 the Council of European Professional and Managerial Staff is celebrating its 20th Anniversary.
== Areas of action == * European model of management: [[competitiveness]] with [[social responsibility]] and cohesion * Delegation guidelines: many P&MS have to delegate tasks and responsibilities * [[Lisbon Strategy|Lisbon strategy]]: competence development, P&MS method to become employability-proof * [[Bologna process]] and the role of P&MS * Develop [[Employment|employment in Europe]]: a labour market focused on high qualifications * [[Research]], innovation and [[higher education]] * Recognition and development of [[Recognition of qualification|qualification]] * [[Mobility rights|Mobility]] with fair conditions * [[Equal opportunities]] for all * [[Work-life balance]]: Guide to handling creative stress * Work environment - [[workload]] management - time management * Clear criteria for work evaluation: P&MS are often not evaluated by time * Promote [[collective bargaining]] at all levels: Competition clause guide, P&MS strive to regulate the use of such clauses{{citation needed|date=November 2013}}
== ''EUROCADRES'' Networks ==
'''''EUROCADRES'' - Femanet''': European network for female managers
'''''EUROCADRES'' - Startpro''': transition from student to professional life
== ''EUROCADRES'' Members ==

'''Extensive stage''', or by its full name, the ''predominantly extensive stage of accumulation'', pertains to one of the [[periodizations of capitalism]], as proposed by Aglietta (1976). It is the first stage of [[capitalism]]. It is also known as the early stage.
During the extensive stage, room exists for the growth of production and capitalist [[means of production]], including [[wages]] and modes of [[employment|labor]]. It is characterized by high rates of [[economic growth]]. When the extensive stage ends, it is followed by the [[intensive stage]] (intensive accumulation).
[[Karl Marx]] described this stage as exhibited in England as "The so-called primitive accumulation".
==References== *Aglietta, Michel, ''Régulation et crises du capitalisme'' Maspéro, Paris, 1976 *Aglietta, Michel, ''A Theory of Capitalist Regulation'', Verso, London, 1979 (English translation of above) *Marx, Karl, ''Capital I'', especially Part VI: "The so-called primitive accumulation", 1867. Several editions.
{{DEFAULTSORT:Extensive Stage}} [[Category:Capitalism]]

'''Fashion Malawi Edition''' or "F.A.M.E" is the first organization in [[Malawi]] that works to market and develop the Malawian fashion Industry through capacity building and professional development training. It was founded in 2010 by Zilanie Gondwe Nyundo and Inge Knapen to build a fashion in industry in Malawi after identifying voids in a previously underdeveloped industry.<ref>http://fame.mw/team/</ref><ref>http://www.mimeta.org/mimeta-work/fame-malawi.html</ref> They are Malawi's leading fashion organization and a pioneer in Malawi's fashion industry. They regularly host national fashion shows in Malawi that have received public acclaim. This includes the [[Kia Motors|Kia]] Malawi Fashion Show.<ref>http://www.malawivoice.com/2012/11/29/htd-motors-hosts-fashion-malawi-edition-2012the-gala-will-line-up-malawis-designers-2012/</ref> They are credited for creating an industry which created space for fashion related businesses to grow in Malawi. They are credited for launching the career of fashion designer [[Lily Alfonso]]. In November 2012, they announced that they will host Malawi's first " Malawi Fashion Week".<ref>http://www.nyasatimes.com/2012/07/14/malawis-designer-lilly-alfonso-set-for-africa-fashion-week-london/</ref>
==Industry and capacity building work== FAME has been supporting the fashion industry at the grassroots level since inception.This includes capacity building in the industry.<ref>http://www.mimeta.org/mimeta-work/fame-malawi.html</ref> They are credited for fostering the growth of a fashion industry in Malawi. Malawi has seen the growth of new fashion related businesses since their inception, including modelling agencies, fashion houses, and fashion photography.They also engage in professional development workshops, including the finance training for students to Don Bosco Technical College and Samalani Youth Center.<ref>http://www.malawivoice.com/2013/02/07/press-release-fame-malawi-fashion-week-44495/</ref><ref>http://www.mimeta.org/mimeta-work/fame-malawi.html</ref> In attempts to grow the industry, they also support and sponsor events by fashion organizations in Malawi.<ref>http://www.manaonline.gov.mw/index.php/entertainment/item/2216-malawi-to-have-two-separate-fashion-week-events</ref>
==FAME events== FAME creates a platform where the Malawi fashion industry can showcase their work. There events have attracted local, regional and international talent in its events.<ref>http://www.bnltimes.com/index.php/daily-times/headlines/arts/12734-designer-nyasulu-triumphs-in-2012-fame</ref> local talent has included Tuccie Creations, Memory Chimchere of the Diva Yn label, and Debbie Gadama of Phade label, Manuka Fashions, and Isaac Bukhu of Haus of Gola.<ref>http://www.manukafashion.com/events.html</ref> International designers have included Peggy 'O' (Kenya) and Pallade Segapo (South Africa), Mustafa Hassanali (Tanzania), Mehmuna Ibrahim-Schumann (Mali).<ref>http://mwnation.com/entertainment-the-nation/13336-fashion-buds-ready-for-fame-2012</ref><ref>http://www.manaonline.gov.mw/index.php/entertainment/item/1347-local-and-international-designers-in-designer-showcase</ref> Fame organized a fashion show as a part of the [[African Movie Academy Awards]] nomination gala that took place in Malawi in March 2013.<ref>http://www.mwnation.com/entertainment-the-nation/16686-amaa-fame-in-fashion-extravaganza</ref>
===Malawi Fashion Week=== A leader in Malawi's fashion industry, in November 2012, FAME announced that it will host Malawi's first ever Fashion Week in 2013.<ref>http://www.manaonline.gov.mw/index.php/entertainment/item/2216-malawi-to-have-two-separate-fashion-week-events</ref>
==FAME Awards== FAME recognizes talent in Malawi by awarding the 'best designer' and 'top model'.<ref>http://www.malawivoice.com/2012/11/29/htd-motors-hosts-fashion-malawi-edition-2012the-gala-will-line-up-malawis-designers-2012/</ref>
===Best Fashion Designer Award winners=== *Yavinde Nyasulu, 2012<ref>http://www.manaonline.gov.mw/index.php/entertainment/item/2216-malawi-to-have-two-separate-fashion-week-events</ref> *Clemoh Sato, 2011<ref>http://www.manaonline.gov.mw/index.php/entertainment/item/2216-malawi-to-have-two-separate-fashion-week-events</ref> *[[Lily Alfonso]], 2010 <ref>http://www.eufrika.org/wordpress/2012/07/malawis-lilly-alfonso-designs-and-sews-her-way-towards-stardom/</ref>
===Model of the Year Award winners=== *Micheal Kazembe, 2012 *Nomonde Sunshine,2011
===Upcoming Designer of the Year Award winners===
*Tawile Kumsinda, 2015

{{Infobox person | name = Frederick Estcourt Bucknall | image = Frederick Estcourt Bucknall.jpeg | alt = | caption = | birth_date = 6 July 1835<ref>''London, England, Church of England Births and Baptisms, 1813-1917''</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=PRG 101/16 Research note on the career of Frederick Estcourt Bucknall |url=http://www.slsa.sa.gov.au/archivaldocs/prg/PRG101_16_Hardy_researchnote_transcript.pdf |publisher=State Library of South Australia |accessdate=23 July 2018}}</ref> | birth_place = [[London]], England | death_date = {{dda|1896|6|4|1835|7|6|df=yes}} | death_place = [[North Adelaide]], [[South Australia]] | other_names = | occupation = politician, businessman, brewer }}
{{EngvarB|date=January 2017}} {{Use dmy dates|date=January 2017}}
'''Frederick Estcourt Bucknall''' (6 July 1835 – 4 June 1896) was an English-born publican, brewer and politician in the early days of the colony of [[South Australia]].
==Life== [[File:Estcourt House, Tennyson.jpg|thumb|Estcourt House, [[Tennyson, South Australia|Tennyson]], built by Bucknall in 1881-3.]] Bucknall was a member of the Estcourts of [[Shipton Moyne|Estcourt]], an influential old family, in the counties of [[Gloucester]] and [[Wiltshire]], but born in London, where his father, William Bucknall of [[Crutched Friars]], was Commodore of the [[Royal Thames Yacht Club]].<ref name=SAR>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article53688178 |title=The Late Mr. F. E. Bucknall |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=5 June 1896 |accessdate=10 February 2013 |page=5 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
Shortly after he arrived in South Australia around 1860<ref name=SAR/> via [[Melbourne]], the original [[River Torrens#Torrens_Lake|Torrens Dam]] was nearly completed, and he built a fleet of fine pleasure craft which he placed on the lake for hire, but the dam failed and was washed away, putting paid to his enterprise. He built a boatshed on the [[Port River]] to the south-east of where the Jervois Street bridge was later built, and created a great deal of interest in [[sculling]] on the Port River. He gained approval as a Licensed Victualler and built the South Australian Club Hotel in St Vincent Street, [[Port Adelaide]] near the site of his boatshed.<ref name=SAR/> He married the widow of Mr. Henry Haussen, a proprietor of the [[Hindmarsh Brewery]].<ref name=late>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article34549091 |title=The Late Mr. F. E. Bucknall |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=5 June 1896 |accessdate=10 February 2013 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
In 1878 Bucknall and [[Arthur Harvey (Australian politician)|Arthur Harvey]] (later to be his parliamentary colleague) formed the Grange Land and Investment Company, to develop the suburb of [[Grange, South Australia|The Grange]].<ref>http://www.charlessturt.sa.gov.au/webdata/resources/files/Local_history_factsheet_-_Grange.pdf Charles Sturt Council: ''A brief history of the suburb Grange''</ref>
The business prospered and he became a wealthy man, in 1883 building a magnificent mansion "Estcourt House" on the seafront between The Grange and [[Glanville, South Australia|Glanville]]. He and Mrs. Bucknall went on a visit to England. While they were away the land boom turned to bust, and with the failure of the [[Commercial Bank of South Australia]] in 1886, he lost much of his fortune<ref name=late/> and was forced to relinquish his mansion to the [[AMP Society]] and find employment in the office of E. Benda and Co. of [[Grenfell Street, Adelaide|Grenfell Street]].<ref name=late/>
Bucknall died at his residence in Childers Street, [[North Adelaide]].
===Politics=== Bucknall entered Parliament as a member for [[Electoral district of West Torrens|West Torrens]] on 8 April 1881<ref>{{cite SA-parl |pid=3659 |name=Frederick Estcourt Bucknall}}</ref> as a colleague of [[W. H. Bean]], and was elected for another three years in 1884 with Arthur Harvey ( – 25 January 1902) with a break 1885–1886 while he visited England for his health.<ref name=SAR/>
Bucknall was a supporter of projects to build the [[Outer Harbor, South Australia|Outer Harbor]] and the [[Central Australia Railway|North–South Railway]], but for some he was remembered as having instituted mandatory [[horse trough]]s outside licensed premises.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article58840791 |title=Early Breweries. |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)|The Mail]] |location=Adelaide |date=27 November 1926 |accessdate=12 February 2013 |page=17 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref>
===Civic life=== Bucknall was Mayor of [[City of Charles Sturt|Hindmarsh]] in 1881, 1882 and 1883, a position he filled with distinction.
==Other interests== In his youth he was a boxer, athlete and president of the Hindmarsh Cricket Club, of which he was patron for over ten years prior to his death.<ref name=late/>
He was an enthusiastic rower, swimmer and yachtsman. He went in for boatbuilding, and owned the yachts ''Brilliant'', ''Rosa'' and ''Enchantress'', which he bought from Sir [[Thomas Elder]] (and eventually sold to Mr. Cunningham).
He was for some time secretary of the Licensed Victuallers' Association, and president for six years. He was made a life member in recognition of this service.
He was an excellent musician, and was at one time organist of the South Australian Grand Lodge of Freemasons, of which he was a member.<ref name=SAR/>
==Family== On 1 October 1874<ref name=":0">GenealogySA, SA BDM, https://www.genealogysa.org.au</ref> he married Rosa Haussen (née Catchlove) (7 December 1840<ref name=":0" /> – 23 November 1899<ref name=":1">WA BDM http://www.bdm.dotag.wa.gov.au/_apps/pioneersindex/</ref>), the widow of brewer [[Henry Herman Haussen]] (1830–1870);<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article39195850 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=29 December 1870 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> her children by her first husband included: * Emily Mary Haussen (4 May 1859 - 1914)<ref name=":0" /> married Harry Walker ( – 25 November 1886)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article45847960 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=2 December 1886 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> on 20 April 1881<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article43158397 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=3 May 1881 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * Rosa Henrietta Haussen (2 November 1860 – 29 November 1915)<ref name=":0" /> married [[Arthur Wellington Ware]] (1867 – 29 January 1927)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article54878648 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=31 January 1927 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> on 11 March 1884<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article5181808 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)|The Advertiser]] |location=Adelaide |date=11 March 1909 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=6 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * Ellen Florence Haussen (12 April 1862 – 9 February 1878)<ref name=Law>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article42992971 |title=Law and Criminal Courts |newspaper=[[South Australian Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=23 December 1878 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=1 Supplement: Supplement to the South Australian Register |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * Ada Haussen (3 February 1864 – 29 December 1952)<ref name=":0" /> married William John Allsop Begg (c. 1866 – 29 September 1947)<ref name=":0" /> * Henry Spencer "Spence" Haussen (3 September 1865<ref name=":0" /> – 1942 Wyong, NSW)<ref>NSW BDM https://familyhistory.bdm.nsw.gov.au</ref> * Amelia Haussen (26 January 1869 - )<ref name=":0" /> married architect Arthur Dan Bendle Garlick (c. 1863 – 27 June 1901)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article21264059 |title=Family Notices. |newspaper=[[The Queenslander]] |date=6 July 1901 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=8 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> on 8 April 1890 * Frederick George Haussen (21 April 1867- 10 August 1875)<ref name=":0" /> * Anna Hermanna Haussen (6 January 1871 – 14 March 1943)<ref name=":0" /> married solicitor George Andrew Greer ( – 1 May 1905)<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article56676704 |title=Poison in Mistake |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=3 May 1905 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> on 18 June 1890 Children by her marriage to Bucknall were three daughters and a son, born in Adelaide, South Australia <!-- *daughter 29 October 1875 * second daughter Flora Forest Bucknall 31 March 1877 – 1 November 1883--> * Louisa Bucknall (29 October 1875<ref name=":0" /> - 1957<ref name=":1" />). She married Charles John Smith in 1899<ref name=":1" /> in Perth Western Australia, where she died. * Flora For(r)est Bucknall (31 March 1877 - 1 November 1883)<ref name=":0" />. * Frederick Bucknall, jun. (23 May 1878<ref name=":0" /> – c. November 1903) lost in the sinking of the [[Loch Bredan (barque)|Loch Bredan]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article55690478 |title=The Barque Loch Bredan |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)|The Register]] |location=Adelaide |date=25 January 1904 |accessdate=11 February 2013 |page=4 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> * Isabelle Bucknall (c.1880 - 29 August 1946)<ref name=":0" />. Unmarried. <!--*daughter Isabelle 27 June 1880 – 28 August 1946 * daughter 28 September 1881 * daughter 27 June 1888-->
Rosa married one more time, to John Huxtable Wesley Perryman<ref name=":1" /> (c. 1837 – 1923) and moved to [[Mount Magnet, Western Australia]].
It should be noted that, by the terms of their father's will, the children of H. H. Haussen were very well provided for<ref name=Law/> and were prominent in business and society, while those of F. E. Bucknall shared their parents' straitened circumstances, and have lapsed into obscurity.
==Memorials== Estcourt House was purchased by the trustees of the legacy of Jessie Brown (ca.1826 – 13 November 1892), wealthy widow of pastoralist [[James Brown (Australian pastoralist)|James Brown]] of Avenue Ranges station (near [[Naracoorte]]) and Waverley House, [[Glen Osmond, South Australia|Glen Osmond]], for the care of crippled children (most suffering or recovering from tuberculosis, poliomyelitis or rheumatic fever) and the aged blind.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article146996298 |title=Friday, November 18, 1892. |newspaper=[[The Narracoorte Herald]] |location=SA |date=18 November 1892 |accessdate=6 July 2014 |page=2 |publisher=National Library of Australia}}</ref> The building was the prominent location for the 1990 movie ''[[Struck by Lightning (1990 film)|Struck by Lightning]]''.<ref name="imdb">{{cite web|url=https://www.imdb.com/title/tt0100709/locations?ref_=tt_dt_dt |title=Struck by Lightning (1990) – Filming Locations – IMDb |<!--########## IMDb filming locations for Struck By Lightning (1990) #########--> |publisher=imdb.com|accessdate=19 May 2016}}</ref>

'''General partner''' is a person who joins with at least one other person to form a business. A general partner has responsibility for the actions of the business, can legally bind the business and is personally liable for all the business's debts and obligations.<ref>{{cite web|title=DEFINITION OF 'GENERAL PARTNER'|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/generalpartner.asp|website=[[Investopedia]]|publisher=investopedia.com|accessdate=27 November 2015}}</ref>
'''Advantages and Disadvantages'''
A partnership can be a beneficial choice of business entity for legal, medical or creative professionals who want to expand their business reach. The disadvantages of being a general partner pertain to the issue of liability. General partners are jointly and severally liable for the partnership's legal obligations including contracts and personal injury suits.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.investopedia.com/terms/g/generalpartner.asp|title=General Partner|last=Staff|first=Investopedia|date=2004-02-22|work=Investopedia|access-date=2018-10-05|language=en-US}}</ref>
General partners are required in the formation of a: * [[General partnership]] * [[Limited partnership]]

'''George Manook''' ({{lang-hy|Ջորջ Մանուկ}}); (Gevork Manuch Merchell/Manukian Manuchariants ({{lang-hy|Գևորգ Մերշել/ Մանուկյան Մանուչարյանց}})), an [[Armenians|Armenian]] merchant of [[Java]], was among the richest figures in the [[Dutch East Indies]], and on several occasions lent large sums of money to the Dutch government. He left behind a fortune of five million [[guilder]]s when he died.
== Biography == He was born in [[New Julfa]], in [[Persian Empire|Persia]], in 1763 or 1767 and died on 24 October 1827 in [[Jakarta|Batavia]]. He died a bachelor.
After significant bequests to the [[Armenian College (Kolkata)]], the [[Armenian School (Madras)|Armenian School]] of Madras ([[Chennai]]), and ecclesiastical establishments in [[Armenia]], [[Jerusalem]] and [[New Julfa]], he left the balance of his estate to his two sisters and his late brother's son.
==References== *Jacob Seth Mesrovb, History of the Armenians in India from the Earliest Times to the Present Day (published by the author, Calcutta 1937) 190 pp at page 132.

{{Infobox person | name = Gil Dov Blutrich | birth_date = 10 October 1965 | birth_place = Ra'anana, Israel | residence = Toronto, Ontario, Canada | occupation = Founder of Mishorim Development and Skyline Investments }}
'''Gil Dov Blutrich''' ([[Hebrew language|Hebrew]]: גיל דוב בלוטרייך; born 10 October 1965) is an Israeli-Canadian [[real estate]] [[Entrepreneurship|entrepreneur]] and [[Philanthropy|philanthropist]] the founder of Skyline Investments and its holding company Mishorim Development. He is listed as 162nd on the Israeli financial news magazine the Marker's 2016 Richest People in Israel list with a personal net worth of $142 million USD.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.themarker.com/magazine/1.2971656|title=500 העשירים: האיש שחזר לפיסגה עם 8.3 מיליארד דולר|last=אבריאל|first=איתן|work=TheMarker|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref>
== Biography == Blutrich was born in [[Tel Aviv|Ra’anana]], [[Israel]] where he founded Israeli real estate firm Mishorim Development with his partner Danny Herzohg in 1990 at the age of 25.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.theglobeandmail.com/report-on-business/gil-blutrich-building-on-the-foundations-of-history/article4477800/|title=Gil Blutrich: Building on the foundations of history|last=BLACKWELL|first=RICHARD|date=2012-08-12|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-ca}}</ref> Based out of Ra’anana, Mishorim focused on office spaces and revitalisation of the city’s industrial area and today also holds commercial properties in the United States.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/research/stocks/private/snapshot.asp?privcapId=39102675|title=Mishorim Development Ltd.: Private Company Information - Bloomberg|website=www.bloomberg.com|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref>
Seeking to expand beyond Israel’s Sharon area, in 1998 he relocated his family to [[Toronto]], [[Ontario]], Canada where he opened Mishorim subsidiary Skyline Investments.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://www.bigpictureconferences.ca/PreviousConferences/CHIC/2012/index5883.html?PAGEPATH=Speakers/Gil_Blutrich&ID=41836|title=Gil Blutrich {{!}} Hotel Invest|website=www.bigpictureconferences.ca|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> It’s in this period that Gil became the sole owner and President of both companies. By 2004, Blutrich was awarded [[Ernst & Young|Ernst & Young’s]] prestigious [[Ernst & Young Entrepreneur of the Year Award|Entrepreneur of the Year Award]] for Ontario for his work with Skyline Investments.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.dolcemag.com/successstories/israeli-born-entrepreneur-gil-blutrich/5751|title=Gil Blutrich of Skyline International Development Inc.|date=2010-09-09|work=Dolce Luxury Magazine|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Skyline was further named in Deloitte’s 2013 and 2014 Best Managed Companies in Canada lists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/skyline-international-renamed-as-one-of-canadas-best-managed-companies-by-deloitte-1998800.htm|title=Skyline International Renamed as One of Canada's Best Managed Companies by Deloitte|last=|first=|date=March 10, 2015|website=Market Wired|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 15, 2017}}</ref> In 2013, he was named as the leader of a new generation of entrepreneurs in real estate by the Israeli newspaper [[Yedioth Ahronoth|Yediot Aharonot]].<ref name=":0" />
In 2007 and 2014 respectively, both companies were taken public on the [[Tel Aviv Stock Exchange]] where they are currently traded.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.buzzbuzzhome.com/2011/05/buzz-talk-with-gil-blutrich-interview.html|title=Buzz Talk with Gil Blutrich [INTERVIEW]|date=2011-05-11|work=BuzzBuzzHome News|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://renx.ca/skyline-adds-u-s-mountain-resort-to-it-portfolio/|title=Skyline adds U.S. mountain resort to its portfolio - Real Estate News Exchange (RENX)|date=2014-08-28|work=Real Estate News Exchange (RENX)|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref> Today, Skyline is a mainstay of Ontario’s resort industry with ownership of three popular sites: [[Deerhurst Resort|Deerhurst]], [[Oro-Medonte|Horseshoe Valley Ski Resort]], and the [[Blue Mountain (ski resort)|Blue Mountain Village]]. Both Skyline and Mishorim have been expanding to commercial properties in the US including hotels and malls including [[Bear Valley (resort)|Bear Valley]] in California and the [[Renaissance Cleveland Hotel]] and the [[Cleveland Arcade|Hyatt Cleveland Arcade]] in Ohio.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skylineinvestments.com/portfolio|title=Portfolio {{!}} Skyline Investments|website=www.skylineinvestments.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> Skyline is valued at $500 CAD million.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.skylineinvestments.com/about-skyline|title=About Skyline {{!}} Skyline Investments|website=www.skylineinvestments.com|language=en|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref>
Blutrich also serves as an [[honorary consul]] to the state of [[El Salvador]] in Canada.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://qspace.library.queensu.ca/bitstream/handle/1974/8590/diplomatic-consular-2007-12-eng.pdf;jsessionid=F2018A50C2627EAA7815A0479FFCF5C2?sequence=27|title=Diplomatic, Consular & Other Representatives in Canada (2007)|last=|first=|date=2007|website=Queens University Library|publisher=Department of Foreign Affairs and International Trade of Canada|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=6 June 2017}}</ref>
== Charitable work == In 1995, Blutrich founded the organisation Atid Varod (Hebrew: עתיד ורוד) "Brighter Future" which is a billboard advertising [[social business]] in his previous hometown of Ra’anana.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.thestar.com/life/homes/2011/08/26/builder_offers_youth_a_bright_future.html|title=Builder offers youth a bright future {{!}} Toronto Star|website=thestar.com|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> This project brought together business and social responsibility by employing at-risk youth outside the formal school system (age 16-18) who are trained in marketing, sales, and consulting to ensure both a successful company and long term benefit for its employees. The municipality of Ra’anana granted the organisation a franchise of 200 billboards on the main thoroughfares in the city to support the project.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://varod.signs.org.il/|title=עתיד ורוד|website=varod.signs.org.il|language=he|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref> Today, Atid Varod has spread throughout Israel.
Blutrich was the founder and first Chairman of the Israeli Forum in 2005, a Toronto-based Israeli-expat community that attempts to deepen the links between Israeli and North American Jews, as well as Canadian society as a whole.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cjnews.com/news/federation-body-aims-integrate-israelis|title=Federation body aims to integrate Israelis - The Canadian Jewish News|last=Reporter|first=Sheri Shefa, Staff|date=2008-12-18|work=The Canadian Jewish News|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref> The Forum includes various wings including the Canada-Israel Chamber of Commerce, Hamifgash (an Israeli cultural organisation), and Kachol Lavan (an Israeli-education school system for expats). In 2008, thousands of other organisations joined the Forum to create one of the strongest non-religious connective organisation between Israelis and the Jewish diaspora.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.cjnews.com/news/toronto-israelis-unite-single-organization|title=Toronto Israelis unite in single organization - The Canadian Jewish News|last=Gordon|first=Dave|date=2008-06-04|work=The Canadian Jewish News|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
Prioritising social responsibility in business, Blutrich has also connected Skyline to other charities including Trees Ontario, Clean the World, and [[Make-A-Wish Foundation|Make-a-Wish Canada]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.hoteliermagazine.com/2013-hotel-regional-company-of-the-year-skyline-hotels-and-resorts/|title=2013 Hotel Regional Company of the Year: Skyline Hotels and Resorts - Hotelier Magazine|date=2013-12-09|work=Hotelier Magazine|access-date=2017-06-16|language=en-US}}</ref>
Blutrich was the Director of "Ve'ahavta" in Toronto, a non-profit organisation focused on fighting homelessness in Toronto and other humanitarian issues around the world.<ref name=":0" />
In support of the arts, Blutrich was also a Director at the [[ReelWorld Film Festival]], a festival promoting diversity in the Canadian arts.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bigpictureconferences.ca/PreviousConferences/CHIC/2010/index6e52.html?pagePath=Speakers/Gil_Blutrich&id=21759|title=Hotel Invest {{!}} Gil Blutrich|website=www.bigpictureconferences.ca|access-date=2017-06-16}}</ref>

This award is presented "for exceptional managerial leadership in the fields of interest to the IEEE". Recipients of this award will receive a certificate and a crystal sculpture.<ref name="IEEE-ErnstWeber-Award">{{cite web|url=http://www.ieee.org/about/awards/recognitions/weber.html |title=IEEE Ernst Weber Engineering Leadership Recognition |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=November 21, 2010}}</ref>
The award was initially called the '''IEEE Engineering Leadership Recognition Award''', but in 1996 renamed to honor [[Ernst Weber (engineer)|Ernst Weber]]. He was the first President of the IEEE and one of the founders of the U.S. [[National Academy of Engineering]].<ref name="IEEE-ErnstWeber-Award"/><ref name="IEEE-ErnstWeber">{{cite web|url=http://www.ieeeghn.org/wiki/index.php/Ernst_Weber |title=IEEE Global History Network - Ernst Weber |publisher=IEEE |accessdate=November 21, 2010}}</ref>

{{unreferenced|date=October 2011}} '''Jeux du Commerce West''', '''JDC West Business Competition''' or informally, '''JDC West''' is an annual business competition featuring top business schools and students from across [[Western Canada]], as well as the largest undergraduate business competition in Western Canada. The first competition, hosted by UBC, occurred January 20-23, 2006, and attracted over 400 students. JDC West was modeled after [[:fr:Jeux du Commerce|Jeux du Commerce]] and allows the competition to move from host university/city to host university/city each given year. ==Structure== Each university sends one team of 50+ representative students to participate respectively in one of 10 Academic Competitions, 1 Parliamentary Debate, 1 Athletic Competition or 1 Social Competition. Points are awarded and accumulated towards a team being declared "School of the Year". ===Academics=== There are 10 core Academic Competitions. That being said, an organizing committee may add any number of additional academic cases, providing that the core academic cases (listed below) are included. Each competition has 3 students from each team participate. In each case competition participants have a fixed amount of time to review the facts and prepare before presenting to the industry judges and experts. Current academic events for JDC West are: * [[Accounting]] * [[Business Strategy]] * [[Entrepreneurship]] * [[Finance]] * [[Human Resource Management]] * [[International Business]] * [[Business Technology Management]] * [[Marketing]] * [[Not-for-profit Business Strategy]] (added in 2009) * [[Taxation]] (removed for 2019) * Operations Management (added for 2019) ===Debate=== Each debate team has 4 students. They have 30 minutes to review the proposal before presenting. As it is in [[Parliamentary Debate|parliamentary style]], one team is designated ''Team Government'' and the other ''Team Opposition''. ===Athletics=== The hosting school chooses the sport each year. The teams include both male and female competitors. *2006: Indoor Soccer (Futsol) *2007: Handball *2008: Dodgeball *2009: Volleyball, Westcoast Kickball, Inner-tube Water Polo, Relay (6 X 200) *2010: Indoor Soccer played on two 190 x 90’ fields on FIFA sanctioned Polytan artificial turf. *2011: Inner-Tube Water Basketball & Ultimate Frisbee *2012: Flag Football & [[Yukigassen]] *2013: Doctor Dodgeball & Netball *2014: Floor Hockey & [[Tchoukball]] *2015: European Handball & [[Schtick (disc game)|Schtick Disc]] *2016: Dodgeball & Floor Ringette *2017: Korfball & DBL Ball *2018: [[Quidditch]] & [[Tchoukball]] *2019: Tsegball & D-Hoops ===Social=== Each social team has 4 students - two males and two females. The social portion of the JDC West competition is arguably the most arduous on its competitors who are on-call for ten social challenges to be completed in less than 48 hours at any time of day or night. These entertaining challenges are known to include spirit, mental and physical challenges that bring the 4 students together in a way no team sport could. These challenges test students adaptability, enthusiasm and team work to the extreme. ===Additional awards=== Participation - Focuses on the spirit of each school during the competition weekend. The team that cheers the hardest, shows up for the most events, and is the life of the party takes the prize. Charity - Has two awards. One for the number of hours that school commits to their charities of choice and the second for the amount of dollars raised for their charity of choice. ==Participating schools== The following schools are or have been participants in JDC West: {| |- |'''University''' |'''Business Faculty Name'''
(if named) !First Year Participating |- |[[British Columbia Institute of Technology]] |[[BCIT School of Business]] |2017 |- | [[Simon Fraser University]] | [[Beedie School of Business]] |2006 |- | [[University of Alberta]] | [[University of Alberta School of Business|Alberta School of Business]] |2006 |- | [[University of British Columbia]] | [[Sauder School of Business]] |2006 |- | [[University of British Columbia Okanagan]] | |2009 |- | [[University of Calgary]] | [[Haskayne School of Business]] |2011 |- |[[University of Lethbridge]] | |2006 |- | [[University of Manitoba]] | [[Asper School of Business]] |2007 |- | [[University of Northern British Columbia]] | |2007 |- | [[University of Regina]] | [[Paul J. Hill School of Business]] |2006 |- | [[University of Saskatchewan]] | [[Edwards School of Business]] |2006 |- | [[University of Victoria]] | [[Peter B. Gustavson School of Business]] |2006 |- | [[University of Winnipeg]] | |2013 |} ==History of the Games== ===History of JDC and JDC West=== The original '''[[:fr:Jeux du Commerce|Jeux du Commerce]]''', French for "Commerce Games" started as a Business Student Competition in 1989 in [[Eastern Canada]]. They were created in 1988 thanks to the initiative of some students of HEC MONTREAL who wanted to strengthen the links between the students of business administration through the province of Quebec. Mister Patrice Bourbonnais was the student heading a team of co-founders, including Patrick Bérard and Benoît Lessard, as well as others students. The School of Hautes Etudes Commerciales (French business school) of Montreal was the first institution host of the Games (Sets) of the Business in January, 1989. [[:fr:Jeux du Commerce|Jeux du Commerce]] grew throughout the years and became one of the largest events hosted by [[:fr:regroupement étudiant des facultés d'administration de l'Est du Canada (RÉFAEC)|REFAEC]]. In 2003, Yannick Denis-Trudel, the president of [[:fr:regroupement étudiant des facultés d'administration de l'Est du Canada (RÉFAEC)|REFAEC]] at the time had a vision to expand "the games" to the rest of Canada. In an attempt to unify the country under the [[:fr:Jeux du Commerce|Jeux du Commerce]] banner, he took on the task of inviting a group of delegates from across Canada to visit the games and see what they were all about. Students returned to their schools excited, but lacked a bit of direction in terms of establishing the games in their own regions. The year after, Yannick made another attempt to get the rest of Canada excited about the games and created a competing team called "Team Rest of Canada" or "Team ROC". The intention was to allow those visiting the games to actively take part in the games, rather than just watch from the sidelines. Student's went back to their respective schools with an excitement to bring [[:fr:Jeux du Commerce|Jeux du Commerce]] to their respective regions. At Roundtable 2005, one bid to host the event in the Western Region by students from the Sauder School of Business at the University of British Columbia, Co-Led by Jeff Potter and Nik Laufer-Edel. Another bid was put forth for the Ontario region by Guelph Humber. The Western bid was approved by the presidents of the western business schools of the Canadian Business School Council and allowed JDC West to take its first steps to be actualized. In 2006, over 1,200 business students from 13 Eastern universities in Canada chose to compete. Since its inauguration, the JDC has become a prestigious annual event noted for its academic excellence and superior teamwork development. Like JDC West, JDC consists of Athletic, Social, Debate and community involvement components. The JDC legacy expanded to Ontario schools in 2009, in a competition branded as JDC Central. Following the success of '[[:fr:Jeux du Commerce|Jeux du Commerce]]' a desire was expressed to create similar games in Western Canada, ultimately leading to a Commerce Competition on a national scale. The Western Games were dubbed ''JDC West''. JDC West has exemplified professionalism and excellence, while focusing on the unique challenges facing a Western Canadian business student. The academic structure of the competition is maintained, encouraging students to strive for excellence and professionalism, while continuing the goodwill and good sportsmanship that JDC has been known for. The JDC West Business Competition was incorporated as a not-for-profit in 2010 prior to JDC West 2011. In 2011, a volunteer Board of Directors was voted in by the Presidents of the participating business schools' students societies in collaboration with their JDC West Team Captains. This board is composed of active JDC West alumni and the current Organizing Committee's External Co-Chair. The board's main roles are to oversee the long-term strategy, risk mitigation, relationship management and high level financial health of the competition to ensure its long-term sustainability. ==Competition venues== {| |- |'''Year''' |'''Location''' |'''Host School''' |'''Co-Chairs''' |'''Students competing''' |''' School of the Year''' |'''Theme''' |'''Winning Team Captain(s)''' |- | 2006 | [[Vancouver]], [[British Columbia]] | [[University of British Columbia]]

[[University of Paris-Sud]] | nationality= [[France|French]] }} '''Jean-Yves Le Gall''' (born 30 April 1959) is an engineering graduate from the [[École supérieure d'optique]] (1981) and holds a doctorate in engineering from the [[University of Paris-Sud]] (1983). He began his career in 1981 as a researcher at the Astronomy Laboratory, French National Scientific Research Center, where he worked on the European scientific satellites project Hipparcos and ISO. In 1985 he joined the Department of Industry and was assigned to the Space Office where he was particularly in charge of relations with the space industry.{{cite web|url=http://www.arianespace.com/about-us/our-management-bios-legall.asp |title=Jean-Yves Le Gall - Chairman & CEO of Arianespace |publisher=[[Arianespace]] |accessdate=6 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606230550/http://www.arianespace.com/about-us/our-management-bios-legall.asp |archivedate= 6 June 2015 |df= }} The Minister for the Postal Service, Telecommunications and Space appointed Le Gall as advisor for space affairs in 1985. In this position, he participated in the definition of [[CNES]] and [[ESA]] programs. In 1993, he joined [[Novespace]], a subsidiary of [[CNES]], of which he was Managing Director. Le Gall was appointed as CNES Deputy Managing Director in 1996. In this function, he was the French Representative to the ESA. In 1998, he was appointed as [[Chairman]] and [[CEO]] of [[Starsem]].{{cite book |last1=Lardier |first1=Christian |last2= Barensky |first2=Stefan |date=12 March 2013|title=The Soyuz Launch Vehicle: The Two Lives of an Engineering Triumph |publisher=Springer-Praxis |chapter= Chapter 5 - The Various Versions |pages=383 |isbn=978-1461454595}} In 2001, he joined [[Arianespace]] as COO. Since 2002 till April 2013 he worked as an Arianespace CEO, was succeeded by [[Stéphane Israël]].{{Cite press release|url=http://www.arianespace.com/news-press-release/2013/4-18-2013-Stephane-Israel.asp |title=Stéphane Israël named Chairman and CEO of Arianespace |publisher=[[Arianespace]] |place=[[Évry, Essonne|Evry]] |date=18 April 2013 |accessdate=6 June 2015 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606204144/http://www.arianespace.com/news-press-release/2013/4-18-2013-Stephane-Israel.asp |archivedate= 6 June 2015 |df= }} Since 2013 Jean-Yves Le Gall is a president of [[CNES]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cnes.fr/web/CNES-en/11369-jean-yves-le-gall-president.php|title=Jean-Yves Le Gall|publisher=[[CNES]]|accessdate=6 June 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150606230633/http://www.cnes.fr/web/CNES-en/11369-jean-yves-le-gall-president.php|archivedate=6 June 2015|df=}} ==Honors and recognitions== Le Gall was named by ''[[Aviation Week & Space Technology]]'' magazine as its 2014 Laureate for Space, based on his work at Arianespace.{{Cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/pentons-aviation-week-announces-winners-of-57th-annual-laureates-awards-honoring-outstanding-achievements-in-aviation-aerospace--defense-248932831.html|title=Penton's Aviation Week Announces Winners of 57th Annual Laureates Awards, Honoring Outstanding Achievements in Aviation, Aerospace & Defense |publisher=[[PR Newswire]]|date=6 March 2014|accessdate=6 June 2015}} In 2006 he received title of "Satellite Executive of the Year" from Via Satellite magazine.{{Cite press Executive of the Year" |publisher=[[Arianespace]] |date=17 January 2006 |accessdate=6 June 2015 |deadurl=yes '''Karel Vinck''' (born 19 September 1938, [[Aalst, Belgium|Aalst]]) is a [[Belgium|Belgian]] businessman. In 1994 the readers of the weekly business magazine Trends chose him to be the Manager of the year. He graduated as a Master in Electrical and Mechanical Engineering from the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] ([[Leuven]], Belgium) and got an MBA from [[Cornell University]] ([[Ithaca, New York]], [[United States]]).
==Career== He started his career at [[Eternit]]. Afterwards Karel Vinck was director of [[Bekaert|Bekaert N.V]] from 1985 up to 1994. In 1995, he started working for [[Umicore|Union Minière]], where he led the restructuring of the company.
He is also a member of the Board of Suez-Tractebel, Tessenderlo Group, of the [[Katholieke Universiteit Leuven]] and of the ''Théâtre Royal de la Monnaie''. He is Co-ordinator of the [[European Rail Traffic Management System]] (ERTMS) with the [[European Commission]], and chairman of [[Cumerio]]. Karel Vinck is honorary chairman of the [[VOKA|Flemish employers association]] (VEV), and Chairman of the [[Flemish Science Policy Council]].
==Sources== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20061217063519/http://www.governance.umicore.com/en/boardDirectors/ Karel Vinck] (Umicore)

With around 80 [[trade fair]]s and over 2,000 [[Business conference|conferences]] annually, Koelnmesse is one of the country's largest trade fair organisers[http://www.koelnmesse.com/en/messenundveranstaltungen/messenveranstaltungen_1.php Koelnmesse.com] and with 284,000 m² exhibition floor area the third largest by area.[http://www.auma.de/de/messemarkt/branchenkennzahlen/internationalemessen/seiten/hallenkapazitaeten.aspx Hall capacities by AUMA e. V.] Hall capacities by AUMA e. V. The Cologne Trade Fair ground was founded in 1922. Until 2005, the trade fair was based in the historic Rheinhallen, and since then moved into new premises next to them. The old [[Fair Tower Cologne]] (''Messeturm Köln'') is a landmark building from 1928 and features a tower restaurant on the top floor. Since 2018, the fair has been undergoing the greatest renovation works in its history. They are expected to last until 2030 and cost €600 million. Two thirds of that amount will be spent renovating the seven southern halls, dating from the 1970s.{{cite web |url=https://www.rundschau-online.de/region/koeln/sanierung-vor-gamescom-die-koelnmesse-modernisiert-sieben-suedhallen-30629372# |publisher=Kölnische Rundschau |title= Die Kölnmesse modernisiert sieben Südhallen| date= 15 June 2018 |language=German |accessdate=2 July 2018}} == Trade fairs == Among others the following [[trade fair]]s are held in Cologne: * [[Anuga Food Fair|Anuga]], the world's most important food and beverage trade fair * [[Anuga FoodTec]], the supplier fair for the food and drink industry * [[Art Cologne]] * [[Dmexco]], the leading international exposition and conference for the digital industry * [[EuVend]], the international trade fair for the [[vending]] industry * [[Gamescom]], most important trade fair for interactive games and entertainment in Europe * [[Imm Cologne]], leading trade fair for the furniture sector * [[Intermot]], international motorcycle, scooter and bicycle fair * Internationale Süßwarenmesse (ISM), world's largest confectionery trade fair * [[Photokina]], the world's leading fair for photography and imaging == Location == [[File:Bahnhofsgebäude Köln Messe Deutz - Gesamtansicht (4416-18).jpg|thumb|[[Köln Messe/Deutz station]]]] The trade fair grounds lie in Cologne's right-Rhenish district of [[Deutz, Cologne|Deutz]], directly adjacent to [[Köln Messe/Deutz station]] to the south. Among others, the station has [[Intercity-Express|ICE]] connections by [[Deutsche Bahn]] to [[Köln Hbf]] and [[Cologne/Bonn Airport station|Cologne/Bonn Airport]]. West of the trade fair grounds lies the ''[[Rheinpark]]'', a 40 hectare large park on the River [[Rhine]], and ''Tanzbrunnen'',[http://www.koelnkongress.de/wEnglisch/locations/tanzbrunnen/index.php Koelnkongress.com] an open-air theater. Apart from the Köln Messe/Deutz station to the south, the Cologne trade fair center is also served by the [[Cologne Stadtbahn]] station ''Koelnmesse'' to the East. {{s-rail-start|noclear=yes}} {{s-rail|title=KVB}} {{s-line|system=KVB|line=3|previous=Köln Messe/Deutz|next=Stegerwaldsiedlung}} {{s-line|system=KVB|line=4|previous=Köln Messe/Deutz|next=Stegerwaldsiedlung}} {{end}} [[File:Titanfall at Gamescom 2013 (9591148650).jpg|thumb|At [[Gamescom]] 2013]] == Subsidiaries == {| class="wikitable" |- | KölnKongress GmbH || [[Cologne]] || {{DEU}} || [http://www.koelnkongress.de/ www.koelnkongress.de] |- | Koelnmesse Ausstellungen GmbH || [[Cologne]] || {{DEU}} || [http://www.koelnmesse.com/ www.koelnmesse.com] |- | Koelnmesse Pte. [[File:Mauro Moretti.jpg|thumb|Mauro Moretti]] '''Mauro Moretti''' (born 29 October 1953) is an Italian executive and former [[CEO]] and General Manager of [[Leonardo S.p.A.]] (formerly Finmeccanica<ref>{{cite news|last1=Ansa News|title=Finmeccanica meeting approves new name, 'Leonardo'|url=http://www.ansa.it/english/news/2016/04/28/-finmeccanica-meeting-approves-new-name-leonardo-_995b8ba5-2ad1-4a79-b9d4-13c8c04becd3.html}}</ref>), from May 2014 to May 2017.
He is also President of ASD – the AeroSpace and Defence Industries Association of Europe (since March 2015), Chairman of the Italy-Japan Business Group (since September 2015), Honorary Chairman of AIAD – the Italian Industries Federation for Aerospace, [[Defense (military)|Defence]] and Security (since July 2014) and President of the Italian [[Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane|FS Italian]] Foundation (since 2013).
He has been CEO of [[Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane]] and chairman of the [[Community of European Railway and Infrastructure Companies]].<ref>[http://www.cer.be/about-us/how-we-work/chairman Organigramma CER CER]</ref><ref>[http://www.uic.org/spip.php?article2015 UIC] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101112051535/http://www.uic.org/spip.php?article2015 |date=12 November 2010 }}</ref> He was [[Mompeo]] mayor in 2004 and he worked as syndacalist.
==Biography== Mauro Moretti joined Ferrovie dello Stato a few months after graduating in Electro Technical Engineering at [[Bologna University]]. His career continued in FS where, after passing a public examination, he reached an executive position. Since then, he has held numerous positions in various sectors and with various companies of the Group. Moretti has been Vice-Director of the Technologies and System Development Division (December 1991), Director of the Technological Development and Rolling Stock Division (March 1993), Managing Director of Metropolis, the Group company for the management, development of real estate assets (February 1994).<ref>{{cite web|author=Eva Böckle|url=http://www.cer.be/press/press-releases/1828-mauro-moretti-becomes-new-cer-chairman |title=CER: Curriculum of Mauro Moretti |publisher=Cer.be |date=21 January 2009|accessdate=24 August 2010}}</ref>
In December 1997 Moretti became the director of "Area Strategica di Affari" (ASA)- Business Strategies, which he managed even after it was transformed into the Infrastructure Division (July 1999). In February 2001 Moretti became a Member of the Board of Directors of Ferrovie dello Stato. In July of the same year, [[Rete Ferroviaria Italiana]] was set up and he was appointed [[Managing Director]]. During his time in FS he also became a cadre of the trade union CGIL Trasporti, arriving to be its Secretary from 1986 to 1991.
In September 2006 he was appointed [[Chief Executive Officer]] of [[Ferrovie dello Stato Italiane]] Spa.
In May 2014 Finmeccanica ([[Leonardo]] since 1 January 2017)<ref>{{cite web|title=Leonardo: articles of association|url=http://www.leonardocompany.com/en/-/statuto-sociale-articles-association|accessdate=13 January 2017}}</ref> Board of Directors appointed Mauro Moretti as new Chief Executive Officer and General Manager of the Group.<ref>[http://www.4-traders.com/FINMECCANICA-SPA-162001/news/Finmeccanica--Board-of-Directors-appoints-Mauro-Moretti-Chief-Executive-Officer-and-General-Manager-18449746/ Finmeccanica: Board of Directors appoints Mauro Moretti Chief Executive Officer and General Manager]</ref>
In 2015, Moretti has launched the company’s reorganisation plan for its competitiveness in global markets. The plan’s objective was to transform the company into a more integrated industrial hub, structured in seven operational divisions. The company’s activities have been focused on the core business of Aerospace, Defence and Security and non-strategic assets, such as the Transport sector, have been sold off. At the same time, Moretti has implemented plans for debt and cost reduction and profitability recovery. In 2016, Moretti also proposed to change the company name from Finmeccanica to Leonardo SpA,<ref>{{cite news|last1=Official Press Release|title=FINMECCANICA: SHAREHOLDERS' MEETING APPROVES THE CHANGE OF THE COMPANY'S NAME AND THE 2015 FINANCIAL STATEMENTS|url=http://www.leonardocompany.com/en/-/cs-28042016}}</ref> a name inspired by the Italian scientist [[Leonardo Da Vinci]].<ref>{{cite news|last1=Reuters|title=Finmeccanica calls on 'Leonardo' to mark turnaround|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-finmeccanica-results-idUSKCN0WI2SN}}</ref>
On 30 January 2017, Moretti was convicted by an Italian court for his alleged role in a train crash in 2009, in which a freight train carrying liquefied gas [[Viareggio train derailment|derailed and caught fire]] at the Italian town of Viareggio, killing 32 people. Moretti received a seven-year jail sentence, but several levels of appeal may take years to resolve the conviction during which time Moretti will be free. His company has said he retains his current role during this legal process.<ref name="">[http://www.defensenews.com/articles/leonardo-ceo-backed-by-board-after-rail-crash-conviction Leonardo CEO Backed by Board After Rail Crash Conviction], Tom Kington, DefenseNews.com, 2017-01-31</ref>
Moretti holds various positions<ref>{{cite web|last1=Web site Finmeccanica|title=Curriculum Vitae Mauro Moretti|url=http://www.leonardocompany.com/documents/63265270/68785075/body_MAURO_MORETTI_CV_Leonardo_29aprile_def_eng.pdf}}</ref> *President of the [http://www.asd-europe.org/ AeroSpace and Defence Industries Association] - ASD - since March 2015 *Honorary Chairman of AIAD, Italian Industries Federation for Aerospace, Defence and Security since 2014 <ref>**[http://www.aiad.it/en/aiad_vertice.wp;jsessionid=C9DDC49D32D5D203AF9B4BD91E17F37C AIAD Federation Bodies]</ref> * President of the [[FS Foundation]] since 2013 * Co-Chairman of the Italian Egyptian Business Council from 2012 to 2014 *Chairman of [[Collegio Ingegneri Ferroviari Italiani]] (Italian Association of Railway Engineers) since 2004 *Member of [[Unindustria]] (Industrialist and Enterprises Association of Rome) *Member of the [[European Management Committee of the International Railway Union]] (UIC) since 2007 *Member of the Board of [[Confindustria]] (Italian Confederation of Industry) since October 2006 *Member of the Board of Federtrasporto (National Confederation of transport and services companies) from May 2007 to April 2012 *Member of the Board of Assolombarda (Industrialist and Enterprises Association of [[Lombardia]]) from 2007 to 2014
==Honours and awards== *Knight of the [[Order of Merit for Labour]]: nominated by [[president of Italy]] [[Giorgio Napolitano]] (2010).<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fsnews.it/cms/v/index.jsp?vgnextoid=1457392c51fe8210VgnVCM1000004016f90aRCRD |title=FS News |publisher=Fsnews.it |date= |accessdate=24 August 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.quirinale.it/elementi/Continua.aspx?tipo=Comunicato&key=10244 |title=Quirinale.it |publisher=Quirinale.it |date= |accessdate=24 August 2010}}</ref> *Honorary degree in [[Mechanical engineering]] from [[University of Cassino]]<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www3.ing.unicas.it/FACOLTA/Info/Laurea-honoris-causa |title=University of Cassino |language=it |publisher=.ing.unicas.it |date= |accessdate=24 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100407052757/http://www3.ing.unicas.it/FACOLTA/Info/Laurea-honoris-causa |archivedate=7 April 2010 |df=dmy-all }}</ref> *Moretti has been awarded in [[Milan]] by the Financial Company Awards 2008 as the best manager of the year.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://travelnostop.blogspot.com/2009/03/fs2-mauro-moretti-e-il-manager-dellanno.html |title=Travel no-stop |publisher=Travelnostop.blogspot.com |date= |accessdate=24 August 2010 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110708071145/http://travelnostop.blogspot.com/2009/03/fs2-mauro-moretti-e-il-manager-dellanno.html |archivedate=8 July 2011 |df=dmy-all }}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2017}} {{Infobox person | name = Abu Omar | image = | image_size = | caption = | birth_name = Mohammed Mohiedin Anis | birth_date = {{birth based on age as of date |70|2017|03|15}}<ref name="jalopnik1" /> | birth_place = | death_date = | death_place = | death_cause = | restingplace = | nationality = Syrian | religion = | ethnicity = | residence = Aleppo, Syria | education = | alma mater = | occupation = Businessman | title = | term = | predecessor = | successor = | known for = Car collection | boards = | salary = | networth = | spouse = | parents = | children = | relations = | website = }} [[File:47 Caddy convertible.jpg|thumb|A 1947 Cadillac convertible (all the cars shown are representative examples, and not from his actual collection)]] [[File:1957 Mercury Montclair 2 door Hardtop (17896059486).jpg|thumb|A 1957 Mercury Montclair]] [[File:Buick Super 56R 1955.jpg|thumb|A 1955 Buick Super]] [[File:1949 Hudson Commodore 6 four-door at 2015 AACA Eastern Regional Fall Meet 03of10.jpg|thumb|A 1949 Hudson Commodore]] [[File:1958 Chevrolet Apache (13404499473).jpg|thumb|A 1958 Chevrolet Apache]] [[File:My Rusty VW thing.jpg|thumb|A VW Thing]]
'''Mohammed Mohiedin Anis''' (born 1946/47), also known as '''Abu Omar''', is a Syrian businessman and car collector, based in [[Aleppo]]. A March 2017 photograph of him sitting on his bed, smoking a pipe and listening to his wind-up record player in a rubble-strewn room has been widely reproduced.<ref name="autogenerated1">{{cite web|url=http://time.com/4701247/aleppo-syria-car-collector/ |author=Katz, Andrew|title=The Man on the Bed |website=Time.com |date=14 March 2017 |accessdate=15 March 2017}}</ref>
==Early life== Anis studied medicine in [[Zaragoza]], Spain, in the 1970s.<ref name="washingtonpost1">{{cite news|last=Selk |first=Avi |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/worldviews/wp/2017/03/14/how-one-mans-pause-became-a-haunting-symbol-of-aleppos-destruction/ |title=How one man’s pause became a haunting symbol of Aleppo’s destruction |newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=14 March 2017 |accessdate=15 March 2017}}</ref><ref name="DiarioMotor">{{cite news|last1=Álvarez|first1=Sergio|title=A pesar de la destrucción del conflicto, este coleccionista de clásicos de Alepo no ha perdido su pasión|url=http://www.diariomotor.com/noticia/coches-clasicos-siria/|accessdate=15 March 2017|work=DiarioMotor|date=15 March 2017}}</ref> His father was a wealthy textile dye entrepreneur.<ref name=laalo>[http://laalo.net/aleppo-car-lover-aims-to-revive-his-wounded-classics-world/ "Aleppo automotive lover goals to revive his ´wounded´ classics | World"], Laalo.net.</ref>
==Career== In the 1970s, he was employed in Italy translating [[Fiat]] car manuals into Arabic.<ref name="jalopnik1"/><ref name="DiarioMotor" /> Later he went back to Syria and opened a cosmetics factory called "Mila Robinson".<ref name="jalopnik1"/><ref name="washingtonpost1"/><ref name="DiarioMotor" /><ref name=laalo />
==Car collection== Anis states that his fascination with classic cars goes back to the 1950 Pontiac that his father drove, and which Anis still owns.<ref name="jalopnik1">{{cite web|url=http://jalopnik.com/syrian-car-enthusiasts-30-car-collection-destroyed-in-c-1793278047 |author= Westbrook, Justin T.| title=Syrian Enthusiast's 30-Car Collection Destroyed In Civil War |website=Jalopnik.com |date=14 March 2017|accessdate=15 March 2017}}</ref>
His first purchase was a 1947 Plymouth.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> His collection now includes dozens of cars from the 1940s and 1950s, and prior to the [[Syrian Civil War]], he had hoped to open a museum in Syria.<ref name="autogenerated1"/> His favourite among his collection is a 1947 Cadillac convertible, now badly damaged, that he bought in a 2005 auction.<ref name="jalopnik1"/> He maintains that "no car collection is complete without at least one Cadillac",<ref name="jalopnik1"/> and his collection also includes a [[VW Thing]], a 1955 [[Buick Super]], a 1949 [[Hudson Commodore]], a 1957 [[Mercury Montclair]], a 1958 [[Chevrolet Apache]], a cargo-van bodied [[Citroen 2CV]], a 1947 Plymouth, as well as other vintage Buicks and Cadillacs.<ref name="jalopnik1"/>
Anis's collection of classic cars reached some 30 vehicles, but has slowly dwindled during the war.<ref name="independentcivil">{{cite news|author=McKernan, Bethan |url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/aleppo-viral-photograph-old-man-story-behind-syria-civil-war-six-years-mohammed-moheidin-anis-abu-a7630691.html |title=Aleppo man: The story behind the viral photograph symbolising six years of Syrian civil war |newspaper=[[The Independent]] |date=15 March 2017|accessdate=15 March 2017}}</ref> In January 2016, he had 24 vintage cars, having lost six to shelling.<ref name="autogenerated2">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-middle-east-35387895 |title=Syrian vintage car collector Abu Omar defies shelling – BBC News |website=Bbc.co.uk |date=23 January 2017 |accessdate=15 March 2017}}</ref> To prevent theft of the cars, he removes the steering wheels and seats. During the conflict, his neighbours stopped rebels who wanted to mount an anti-aircraft gun on a 1958 Chevrolet.<ref name="jalopnik1"/>
He had to leave Aleppo for a time at the height of the [[Battle of Aleppo (2012–16)|Battle of Aleppo]], and when he returned only 13 cars were left (including his 1947 Cadillac convertible, now badly damaged), seven having been impounded by the Syrian police, and 10 either missing or destroyed in the war.<ref name="jalopnik1"/> In March 2017, Anis estimated that altogether, one-third of the collection had been either destroyed or stolen.<ref name="independentcivil"/> He says, "When one of my cars is hit, it's as if I or one of my relatives has been hit. It's as if they were my children, so I come down to check on them".<ref name="jalopnik1" />
==Personal life== Anis lives alone in the formerly rebel-held neighbourhood of al-Shaar in [[Aleppo]], his family having fled due to the war.<ref name="autogenerated2"/> He has eight children with two wives, one in Aleppo, the other in [[Hama]], and would like to leave his cars to his children, two to every boy, one to every girl.<ref name="jalopnik1"/><ref name=laalo /> He speaks five languages, and likes to smoke a pipe while listening to classical music, and to Syrian singers such as [[Mohamed Dia al-Din]].<ref name="washingtonpost1"/><ref name="independentcivil"/>
==References== {{Reflist|30em}}
==External links== * [http://www.gettyimages.co.uk/event/vintage-cars-amidst-the-ruins-of-aleppo-548260839 Slide show of his cars]

{{hatnote|Not to be confused with [[Yusef of Morocco|Moulay Youssef]], Sultan of Morocco (1912–1927)}} {{Infobox royalty | image = | name = Moulay Youssef Alaoui | title = [[Alaouite dynasty|Alaouite Sharif]] | full name = | crown = | suc-type = | royal house = [[Alaouite dynasty]] | father = [[Moulay Ali Alaoui|Prince Moulay Ali]] | mother = [[Lalla Fatima Zohra|Princess Lalla Fatima Zohra]] | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1969}} | birth_place = [[Rabat]], [[Morocco]] | spouse = | issue = | religion = [[Islam]] }} {{Moroccan Royal Family}} ''[[Sharif]] Moulay'' '''Youssef Alaoui''' (born c. 1969 in [[Rabat]]) is a maternal first cousin and a paternal second cousin of [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|Mohammed VI]]. He is reportedly a close friend of king [[Mohammed VI of Morocco|Mohammed VI]] who appointed him as an advisor and regularly appears beside the monarch in official visits, most recently in [[Tunisia]] in June 2014.<ref name=Ayyam>{{cite news|publisher=Al-Ayyam|date=27 March 2014|pages=14–15|title=الأمراء المرافقون للملك الذين لا يعرفهم المغاربة}}</ref>
Sharif Moulay Youssef Alaoui is also an important business man in the country active in the [[hospitality]], [[Tourism]] and [[real-estate]] sectors, sometimes in association with [[Prince Moulay Rachid of Morocco|Prince Moulay Rachid]]. He owns the holding ''Blue Invest'', that controlled the "Tahiti Beach Club" in [[Casablanca]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Le Prince My Youssef victime d’arnaque|publisher=Maroc Hebdo|date=January 2007|author1=Aissa Amourag}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|author1=Aissa Amourag|title=Tahiti Beach Club, Hicham Sedki contre-attaque|url=http://www.maroc-hebdo.press.ma/Site-Maroc-hebdo/archive/Archives_770/html_770/tahiti.html|accessdate=6 June 2014|publisher=[[Maroc Hebdo]]}}</ref><ref name=vieeco>{{cite news|author1=Fadoua Ghannam|title=Affaire du Tahiti Beach Club : les dessous d'un imbroglio|url=http://www.lavieeco.com/news/economie/affaire-du-tahiti-beach-club-les-dessous-d-un-imbroglio-2290.html|accessdate=6 June 2014|publisher=[[La Vie Eco]]|date=29 December 2006}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Le Tahiti Club à la recherche d’un gérant|url=http://www.leconomiste.com/article/le-tahiti-club-la-recherche-d-un-gerant|accessdate=6 June 2014|publisher=[[L'Economiste]]|date=7 March 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Affaire Tahiti Club L’imbroglio des hommes de paille|url=http://www.leconomiste.com/article/affaire-tahiti-clubbrl-imbroglio-des-hommes-de-paille|accessdate=6 June 2014|publisher=[[L'Economiste]]|date=31 January 2007}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Lalla Joumala. Une Alaouite chez les british|url=http://telquel.ma/2014/02/20/lalla-joumala-une-alaouite-chez-les-british_11236|accessdate=6 June 2014|publisher=[[Telquel]]|date=20 February 2014}}</ref>
==Family== He is the youngest son of Prince [[Moulay Ali Alaoui|Moulay Ali]] and Princess [[Lalla Fatima Zohra]] and the brother of Sharif [[Moulay Abdallah ben Ali Alaoui|Moulay Abdallah Alaoui]] and Princess [[Princess Lalla Joumala Alaoui|Lalla Joumala Alaoui]].<ref name=ark>{{cite web|author1=Christopher Buyers|title=The Alawi Dynasty GENEALOGY|url=http://www.royalark.net/Morocco/morocco11.htm|accessdate=5 June 2014}}</ref> He studied at the [[Collège Royal (Rabat)|Collège royal]] in [[Rabat]] in the same class as Prince Moulay Rachid.<ref name=Ayyam/>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Mohammed VI}}

{{distinguish|Richard A. Normann}} '''Richard Normann''' (Finland, 1943 - Paris, November 18, 2003) was a Swedish [[management]] consultant and researcher early in the development of theories of [[service management]], interactive strategy, and offerings.<ref>{{cite web|last=Isaksson|first=Pär|title=Richard Normann död|url=http://www.affarsvarlden.se/hem/nyheter/article261227.ece|publisher=Affärsvärlden|accessdate=20 November 2003}}</ref>
== Biography == Normann received his MBA and then PhD in Business Economics in 1975 at [[Lund University]], leading to a professorship. He was soon working at management consultancy [[Scandinavian Institutes of Administrative Research (SIAR)]] and was its president from 1976 to 1980. He was also a visiting professor at the [[Copenhagen Business School]] and visiting scholar at [[Harvard Business School]]. Being the founder of Service Management Group, SMG in 1980, he later also founded the [[strategy consulting]] firm NormannPartners<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://normannpartners.com/about-us/legacy-richard-normann/|title=The legacy of Richard Normann|last=|first=|date=|website=NormannPartners|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> that bear his conceptual legacy today.
Normann was the one who in the 1970s introduced the concept of mission.<ref>{{cite web|last=Bränfeldt|first=Lars-Eric|title=Gurun om jättarnas strategiska missar|url=http://www.affarsvarlden.se/hem/analyser/article2573372.ece|publisher=Affärsvärlden|accessdate=20 November 2003}}</ref> He was, among other things, strategy consultant for SAS when the airline in the 1980s, during [[Jan Carlzon]] CEO's time, developing the idea, together with Denis Boyle of [http://ipapi.org/wiki/index.php/Moments_of_Truth "moments of truth"] oriented toward business travelers and customers.
Green Templeton College, at Oxford University, honors his memory with the [http://www.gtc.ox.ac.uk/academic/lectures-seminars/annual-richard-normann-lecture.html Annual Richard Normann Lecture].
In the introduction to ''Reframing Business'', [[Henry Mintzberg]] cites Normann as a "significant scholar", "using the consulting opportunity to advance general scholarship, namely our understanding of how this world works".
== Publications == * 1984. Service Management. Chichester: John Wiley & Sons. [The seminal work.] * 1989 (with [[Rafael Ramirez (management researcher)|Rafael Ramírez]]) “A Theory of the Offering: Toward a Neo-Industrial Business Strategy.” In [https://books.google.com/books/about/Strategy_organization_design_and_human_r.html?id=FChHAAAAMAAJ ''Strategy Organisation Design, and Human Resource Management''], ed. Charles C. Snow, 111–128. J.A.I. Press. . * 1991 [https://books.google.com/books?id=eHx4QgAACAAJ ''Service Management: Strategy and Leadership in Service Business''] * 1993 (with [[Rafael Ramirez (management researcher)|Rafael Ramirez]]), [http://hbr.org/1993/07/designing-interactive-strategy/ar/1 "Designing Interactive Strategy"], ''Harvard Business Review'' * 1994 (with [[Solveig Wikström]]) [https://books.google.com/books?id=ZqgOAAAAQAAJ ''Knowledge and Value: A New Perspective on Corporate Transformation''] * 1998 (with [[Rafael Ramirez (management researcher)|Rafael Ramirez]]) [https://books.google.com/books?id=QpYoAQAAMAAJ ''Designing interactive strategy: from value chain to value constellation''] * 2001 [https://books.google.com/books?id=kL3VLsu9zA0C ''Reframing Business: When the Map Changes the Landscape''] * 2006 (with [[Niklas Arvidsson]]), [https://books.google.com/books?id=pEo2AQAAIAAJ ''People as care catalysts: from being patient to becoming healthy'']
== References == {{Reflist}}
